newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-GEC unveils future, but shares fall.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-GEC unveils future, but shares fall.

text.p: Britain's General Electric Co Plc on Tuesday unveiled its long awaited strategic blueprint to take it into the next century, putting defence at the heart of the group and signalling a possible float of its rail/power joint venture.

George Simpson, successor to veteran former managing director Lord Weinstock, announced a key shift away from the old GEC culture of joint ventures towards managed businesses and said GEC-Marconi, the defence-electronics division, will become the new "heart of the group".
But GEC's shares reacted with disappointment, reversing some of the strong gains of recent sessions.
The shares were the biggest FTSE-100 loser, down 20 pence or 5.3 percent at 357.5 pence by 1511 GMT, damped down after hopes of a defence merger were dashed.
Earlier this week, GEC was caught up in a storm of speculation that it might announce news of a defence alliance, or merger talks with British Aerospace Plc (Bae) or Finmeccanica Spa of Italy.
"Sometimes it is better to travel than to arrive," said one industry analyst. "I thought GEC revealed more than I'd expected. But others had obviously expected concrete deals and did not get them."

Another analyst said he was "underwhelmed by the review, adding that the timeframe for returning shareholder value was too long term at two to three years. "Another disappointing year for GEC," he said.

Simpson said GEC's new mission statement was "designed to build Marconi into a global player, spanning all three principle defence electronics markets -- America, Europe and the East -- and to focus the group's industrial electronics and communications activities on existing or potential global leadership positions."

The future of GEC's two main joint ventures was placed under review. Simpson told Reuters that GEC and its French partner Alcatel Alsthom were considering floating their 50-50 rail and power venture GEC-ALSTHOM on the London and Paris stock exchanges.
"We have looked at whether to demerge or float the business and that is the subject of discussion," Simpson told Reuters. "On a personal basis, I think it is best."

He said the float option was "very tax efficient" and would enhance shareholder value. GEC expects a decision within the next three months. If agreed, the float could take between six and nine months to implement.
Explaining the rationale, Simpson said, "That business has become very large. It is beginning to outgrow its parent."
Analaysts estimated such a float could raise a total of between three and three and a half billion pounds ($5 billion), to be split by the partners.
GEC is also considering "repositioning" its telecoms joint venture GPT which is 60 percent-owned by GEC and 40 percent-owned by Siemens AG.

Simpson said he had thought about selling the telecoms stake, but rejected it. "Clearly one option was to sell our stake to Siemens. But I am driven by shareholder value. We will monitor the business and rewrite the charter for that business, as telecoms is a high growth area which GEC should remain in."
GEC said it was now committed to spending its huge cash pile -- valued by Simpson at over two billion pounds -- on investment and acquisition opportunities.

But he said that he was also willing to gear up if necessary. "We are not averse to gearing up GEC. The mere fact that I will now do that is a very significant change in GEC's policy," he told Reuters.
Under Weinstock, GEC traditionally maintained a highly cautious capital structure, with high levels of net cash.
The first call on the cash is now investment. But Simpson made clear that he would not shy from returning cash to shareholders if he ccould find suitable buying opportunities.
"If we can consummate deals I may not be able to return any cash to shareholders. But if there is no way forward on deals, I will return cash," he said.

The review comes against a backdrop of mounting pressure for the European defence industry to consolidate after mega-mergers seen in the U.S. between Lockheed Martin Corp and Northrop Grumman Corp plus Boeing Co and McDonnell Douglas Corp.
Simpson said he was aware of the need to bolster its defence position, but added that GEC-Marconi's order book was at record levels and "I'm not under desperate time pressure to act."
He said, "We are looking at Siemens Plessey (Siemens defence arm which is up for sale) and talking to Finmeccanica..." He said he wanted to "do these things first".
But he added "I am sensitised to the situation with BAe and talk to them regularly as well as to Thomson-CSF in France."
"Clearly in time something will happen in European consolidation and GEC must be part of it."
GEC also announced its annual results, with pretax profits of 1.01 billion pounds before charges in line with forecasts.

However, Simpson warned that as a major exporter the strength of sterling was beginning to bite. It took 19 million pounds off profits last year and could take 45-50 million pounds off profits this year, he said. ($ = 0.594 British Pounds)
